Fun fact. In a supernova, much of the outward momentum that causes the explosion of the star is carried by neutrinos. But neutrinos almost never interact with atoms. If you fire a neutrino through lead, you need 1 light year of lead to have a 50% chance of an interaction with the lead. Yes, 1 light year... they don’t like interacting with other matter.
So this gives you an idea of how many neutrinos are created during a supernova, but also it tells you just how dense the material in the star’s core is that many of the neutrinos actually do interact. The “wall” of collapsing stellar material is so incredibly dense that the neutrinos just can’t help hitting it and repelling it outwards.if you want to know more, I recommend the Crash Course Astronomy course with Phil Plait. It’s epic :)

I would like to address something here. She uses the word supernova when she actually means star. The expulsion of the stuff from the outer layers of the star after the implosion due to gravitational collapse is what we know as supernova. If you shine two torches (flashlights) into each other, what speed do the opposing light beams "collide" withe each other? Light is not meat to go faster than the speed of light, relative to anything else.
They say a rocket can only accelerate to double the exhaust velocity. According to relativity, nothing is actually traveling until you have an observer. Then he can be traveling and the other one not. To find out which one is traveling, we need another observer. Speed is relative, so what's stopping a rocket from accelerating past double exhaust velocity? If there was no observer, how can tere really be any "double exhaust velocity", or any velocity at all, for that matter? So what's stopping it from further accelerating? But if the rocket was in the middle of space, with no observer, it wouldn't be going any "velocity" only accelerating and decelerating. So there is no such thing as "double the exhaust velocity" without an observer. So there is nothing stopping the rocket from accelerating to faster than it's exhaust velocity. Robert Zubrin, a famous Mars mission physicist makes the claim that a rocket has limited velocity to twice it's exhaust velocity.

I wish there had been a warning included about double bouncing in this vid. People don't realize, but injuries where your foot literally unhinges from the ankle are a common occurrence (google it, warning graphic), such injuries normally happen several times a year at trampoline parks and are one of the reasons many pediatric groups recommend against backyard trampolines. The reason for these injuries is just like in the video, a larger kids momentum gets transferred to a smaller kid whose ankles can't support that amount of force, causing their feet to literally snap off.

A nice example of the role of mediation in collisions. In fact, it can be proven that in the limit of an increasing number of mediator particles of intermediary masses, the efficiency of the energy transfer will tend to 1, that is, all the energy will be transferred from the first (more massive) to the last (less massive) particle, as it happens in a Newton pendulum, where all masses are equal.

This happened in my physics engine aswell. I dropped a heavy object on top of a small one, and since I had not added any friction, the small ball absorbed all the kinetic energy of the heavy object, and started to bounce like crazy until it warped through the large one, and vanished into the sky.

Also, if anyone wants a mathematical method, where the relationship between the masses is finite, of finding how high the top ball will reach, I do not currently have such an equation set, and I can assure you that it would be pretty complicated. I can give some equations that can help you see how the energy, momentum and speed change with each collision. If anyone wants to visualize this mathematically, I suggest using a mathematical grapher program. I constructed a few equations and plugged them into my grapher program, and it really helps visualize the collisions (while also giving whatever mathematical readouts you want). You can do this on paper, but it is so slow that visualizing the mathematics and the collision simultaneously, is almost impossible.

If each ball closer to the ground were infinitely heavier than the one above it, the maximum rebound height (if gravity is constant, and friction is neglected) is Hr=Hd (2^n)-1)^2, where Hr is the rebound height reached by the top ball, Hd is the height that the top (lightest) ball was initially dropped, and n is the amount of balls used. But the relative rebound speed between each set of colliding spheres, is never more than the relative collision speed. This is as I said before, and I can explain this in mathematical proof if anyone finds it necessary to doubt. When I was talking about the maximum height being Hd (n^2), I was referring to the case where the ball beneath comes to a halt upon collision with the top ball. In other words, when the lower ball has three times the mass as the ball above it. If there are more than two balls, and all the balls fall effectively the same distance, each ball must (in order for the top ball to reach a height of Hr=Hd n^2) have a mass of 1+2(1/v) times that of the ball above it, where v is the speed of the ball in question, relative to the stationary frame of reference that the balls were initially dropped from. This speed is (2^n+1)-1, where n is the amount of balls beneath the one in question. If zero balls are beneath it (it is at the bottom), it has an upward speed of not greater than that which it fell at, so the "(1/v)" part of the mass predicting equation can be neglected, leaving mass= 1+2 times that of the ball above it.

The coefficient of restitution is not a constant at varying speeds (or stresses). The golf ball would not bounce 28 feet high, if it fell 40 feet. It might bounce just over 20 feet. The wind would take a lot of energy from the ball, as it fell the first 40 feet.

You should be more careful with using momentum in your explanation here. It's not conserved at all since there is a HUGE external reaction force from the ground in the moment of the bounce (that force actually performs very little work because the displacement is basically 0). I'm not sure what the momentum adds to the explanation to be honest.

I suppose that also kinda explains why it's a bad idea to run into each other with one exercise ball each.

Then again, there's always the analytical and the empirical approach to finding that out...
